text: The day is remembered vividly, December 7th, 1941. At just 15 years old, a curious and impressionable teenager sat in an apartment in Manhattan, captivated by the sounds of the radio. The symphony played softly in the background when suddenly, the broadcast was interrupted. The announcer's voice cut through the music, delivering the shocking news that the Japanese had bombed Pearl Harbor. It felt surreal, like something out of a movie. Parents, having lived through World War I and the tumultuous events leading up to the war in Europe, had sensed that conflict might soon be on the horizon. They were right, but youthful naivety and a sense of invincibility made it difficult to grasp the full weight of what this meant for the future.

text: At that time, my half-brother, who was 18 years older than me and had been born in France, was living with us in a bustling, diverse land known for its vast landscapes and melting pot of cultures. He had completed his military training in France before relocating to this new country, where opportunities seemed endless. When the draft law was enacted in 1940, he believed he was safe, being a citizen of this nation that prided itself on freedom and democracy. But as fate would have it, he was among the first to be called into the army, a force that would soon be engaged in a global conflict. Just before the attack on Pearl Harbor, he wrote to us, excitedly sharing that he would soon be discharged after fulfilling his service. But that letter quickly became irrelevant as the world around us changed overnight, thrusting this nation into a war that would alter its course forever.

text: I was enrolled in a prestigious year-round program at a renowned university known for its rigorous academics and rich history, starting in June of '43. I turned 18 in January of '44, determined to complete my freshman year at this Ivy League institution before the draft caught up with me. The military had a program that allowed you to enlist and defer your call-up until the semester ended, so I decided to enlist in December of '43. I was called up in mid-March, just in time to finish my first year at this esteemed school, famous for its crimson colors and distinguished alumni. It was a bittersweet moment, knowing that my academic pursuits were about to be interrupted by the realities of war.

text: At Camp Stewart, I trained on a large caliber anti-aircraft artillery system designed to intercept enemy aircraft. They selected me and a few others based on our intelligence test scores to work in the director section, where we operated a sophisticated Sperry gyroscope mechanical computer. This device calculated various factors like altitude and wind to help track fast-moving enemy planes and direct our fire with precision. After completing my training, I returned home for a week before being shipped to Camp Hahn, California, where I was assigned to another artillery battalion equipped with similar heavy weaponry. I remember the luxury of working in an air-conditioned trailer while others were outside in the elements, loading shells and preparing the guns for action. We were gearing up for deployment to the Pacific, and I thought how wonderful it would be to be stationed on tropical islands.

text: However, that dream was short-lived. By late September or October, as the world was engulfed in the turmoil of a global conflict, the entire camp was disbanded, and we were all sent to infantry training. I found myself in Texas, waking up at 4:00 AM, marching five miles with full gear, and spending long days in the field, all while the sounds of distant battles echoed in our minds. It was grueling, but I was in great shape by the end of it. After a few weeks, we were sent to Fort Meade, Maryland, a processing center for overseas deployment, where the urgency of the war loomed large. We turned in our old equipment and received new gear, all carefully marked with our names and serial numbers, readying ourselves for the challenges that lay ahead in a world at war.

text: I remember the peculiar way we were transported. Instead of the usual route through New Jersey, we went directly from Fort Meade to a ferry dock. We boarded the Queen Elizabeth, a massive troop transport ship that had never been used for civilian service. With around 16,000 men on board, we were packed into bunks six deep. I was nervous about the journey, especially since we were told to wear life vests and stay within designated areas. As we sailed away from the bustling skyline, with its towering skyscrapers and bright lights reflecting off the water, I caught a glimpse of a famous statue standing proudly in the harbor, a bittersweet reminder of home.

text: The crossing took about four or five days, and I remember feeling seasick for a day or so. When we finally arrived in a picturesque bay, the scenery was breathtaking. Rugged mountains, their peaks often shrouded in mist, rose dramatically around us, and I felt a mix of excitement and apprehension. The landscape was dotted with lush green valleys and shimmering lochs, reflecting the sky above. We unloaded in a port town known for its rich maritime history and boarded troop trains that took us through the rolling hills and quaint villages, where we were fed meat pies and coffee before arriving at our next destination. From there, we boarded a converted freighter run by Sikh soldiers, who were intimidating yet kind. I slept in a hammock for the first time in my life.

text: Eventually, we arrived at a bustling port city known for its rich history and vibrant culture, and boarded freight trains known as "forty and eights." I learned later that the name referred to the capacity of the cars—forty men or eight horses. We were packed in tightly, and after a long journey, we were unloaded in Belgium. text: As we continued our advance, we reached the Elbe River, where we prepared for an assault crossing. We loaded into small wooden boats, and as we paddled across, we were met with machine gun fire and some artillery. I remember one moment vividly when shrapnel struck one of our jeeps, causing the canvas cover to catch fire. Inside, we had heavy, cylindrical shells packed tightly, each one designed to be launched from a tube, their explosive potential a constant reminder of the danger we faced. We all scrambled to put it out, fearing an explosion that could have been catastrophic. After crossing the river, we set up a defensive position on the right flank of the bridgehead, where we spent just one night.

One day, while marching through the woods with my captain, we were ordered to spread out as we approached a town under attack. We took cover in a ditch filled with icy water, which was better than being exposed to enemy fire. We called for tank support to help us locate the source of the onslaught, and eventually, we managed to assault the town.

text: As the fighting subsided, we began to see an influx of refugees fleeing from the advancing Russians. They were desperate to avoid being taken over and sought passage across our pontoon bridges, which we could not allow. Eventually, we retreated from our position and made our way to Bavaria, where we were re-equipped and retrained for the anticipated assault on Japan. We were loading up trucks for maneuvers in Grafenwoehr when a voice, authoritative yet tinged with relief, broke through the bustle: "The war is over, guys. We’re not going to maneuver." It belonged to the man who had led us through countless challenges, his uniform crisp and his demeanor steady, always ready to shoulder the weight of our fears. It was VE-Day, and we were relieved but also uncertain about what lay ahead.

text: After the war in Europe ended, we moved to a picturesque region known for its rolling hills, charming villages, and stunning alpine landscapes, designated as the American zone. It was there that we learned about the end of the war in Japan in August. However, I wasn’t going home just yet. Despite having three battle stars for my service in the Battle of the Bulge, Central Europe, and the Rhineland, I was too young to return home. Instead, I was transferred to a post office unit in a city famous for its beer gardens and vibrant culture, where I found myself among a group of young soldiers, all around 19 years old, while the men running the post office seemed ancient in comparison.

text: In Munich, we quickly learned how to operate a post office. The more experienced individuals, clad in uniforms and bearing the weight of their service, who had been drafted and were managing the postal units soon returned home, leaving us in charge. We lived in apartments with maid service, enjoyed delicious meals prepared by German cooks, and were served by Polish waitresses. It was a surprisingly pleasant life amidst the aftermath of war. I was eventually promoted to sergeant and became the administrative sergeant for the post office, learning all aspects of the job, from sorting mail to handling money orders.

text: Reflecting on that tumultuous period marked by global conflict, I believe history often overlooks the profound impact it had on everyday life. The sheer scale of military involvement and sacrifice, with countless individuals donning uniforms and serving far from home, is difficult to convey through written accounts or films. As a young man, I remember feeling out of place as a civilian surrounded by soldiers and sailors. Rationing became a part of life—shoes, food, gasoline, and tires were all limited due to the demands of the war effort. Blackouts were common; the city was dimmed to protect against enemy air raids and submarines lurking in the waters. My uncle, a chef at a prominent restaurant known for its vibrant nightlife, saw it close because they couldn't risk the lights revealing their location to potential attackers.

text: I remember my father working for Mayor Frank Hague during the Depression, where he had to kick back a portion of his paycheck to the political machine. There were certainly political shenanigans back then, too, like a certain charismatic and flamboyant mayor of a major city known for his larger-than-life personality and a knack for bending the rules. This man, who was often seen as a champion of the common people, somehow managed to secure re-election while serving time behind bars for corruption. It seems that political corruption is a constant in our history, but we must remain vigilant and focused on the important issues that truly matter.

text: I remember the day I decided to dedicate my life to helping others. As a child, I was always the one running around the neighborhood, rescuing fallen birds and tending to my friends when they scraped their knees. I found joy in caring for those in need, whether it was a simple cut or a little bird that required assistance. When the Great Depression hit and my father lost everything, my mother suggested a path that involved service and compassion. It seemed like a perfect fit, so we explored our options. The best institution in New York State at the time was Saint Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie, which was a bit of a trek from our home on Long Island, but we had a summer house nearby. I applied, got accepted, and spent three wonderful years there, learning the art of healing and the science of care. I immersed myself in understanding the human body, mastering the skills of observation, and developing the ability to comfort those in distress. I learned to administer treatments, manage medications, and provide emotional support to patients and their families. Under the guidance of the black Franciscans, a highly educated order of nuns, I grew in my ability to advocate for those who were vulnerable and to bring hope to those in pain.

text: After graduating, I won a scholarship to Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City, where I focused on the intricate workings of the brain and nervous system, studying conditions that affect cognition, movement, and sensation, as well as the surgical techniques to address them. Just as I was completing my training, World War II broke out, and I was asked to join a unit heading overseas. I remember boarding the ship, the Pastura, a former elegant cruise liner now repurposed for the war. We were crammed into staterooms meant for two, with eleven nurses sharing one. The journey across the ocean was nerve-wracking; we had to keep everything dark to avoid enemy submarines. We landed in Casablanca after eleven long days, and from there, we were transported by train to Mateur, where we set up our camp in what had once been a French military training facility.

text: The conditions were challenging. We lived in tents, shared cots, and had to make do with limited facilities. I remember the heat of North Africa, the smell of unburied bodies from the previous battles, and the mud that would seep into our tents during the rainy season. I suffered from trench foot, a painful reminder of those days spent sloshing through mud. But despite the hardships, the young men in their olive drab uniforms, with their distinct accents and unwavering determination, were the bravest individuals I had ever encountered. They faced their injuries with such courage, often cracking jokes to lighten the mood, and it was a privilege to provide care for them.

text: It was in Mateur that I met my husband, Jack. I had been invited to a swim party, and although I had nothing to wear, I fashioned a makeshift swimsuit from a housecoat I had brought along. That day, I met Jack, a Major in the 15th Air Force. We hit it off immediately, discussing everything from theater to our lives back home. He called my Colonel to ask if he could see me again, and to my surprise, the Colonel approved. Our romance blossomed quickly, and we were married on a day notorious for its lighthearted tricks and playful deceptions, when laughter and jesting were the norm, in 1944, in a series of ceremonies that included local Arabic customs and a Catholic service.

text: After the war, returning home on a troop ship brought an unforgettable sight—the Statue of Liberty emerging as the harbor drew closer. A mix of emotions filled the heart: relief, joy, and a sense of accomplishment. With Jack having flown home ahead, a reunion took place in Long Island before heading to his ranch in Los Gatos, California. Life there was beautiful, raising quarter horses in a lovely home, where a nurturing spirit thrived. However, plans for a big family changed when Jack was injured during the war. Eventually, two wonderful children, a boy and a girl, were adopted, bringing immense joy in the roles of a devoted mother and later a loving grandmother, always ready with warm hugs and encouraging words.

text: During my time in a sun-soaked region characterized by vast deserts and bustling markets, I learned a lot about the importance of structure and rules. Life in the service was all about following orders, and I found comfort in that. Having spent years in parochial schools with nuns, I was accustomed to a disciplined environment. I appreciated that in our unit, there was no favoritism; everyone was held to the same standards. It made it easier to get along with my colleagues when we all knew what was expected of us. Fairness was paramount, and I thrived in that kind of atmosphere. The vibrant culture around us, with its rich history and diverse traditions, added depth to our experiences, but the underlying order and discipline were what truly resonated with me.

text: One day, a sergeant approached me, exasperated. "My God," he exclaimed, "there's the damn you-know-what all over the place!" Apparently, some of the individuals, particularly those with thick Southern accents and a laid-back demeanor, were having trouble hitting the target. They just didn’t seem to care where they aimed, often laughing and joking among themselves instead of focusing. In a moment of levity, I jokingly said, "I have to keep doing my nails!" I had a red nail polish kit with me, even though we weren’t allowed to wear it. I don’t know why I had it, but I decided to make the best of the situation. I handed the sergeant the red polish and said, "Here, take this and make a bull's eye."

text: I remember the day I made the decision to enlist in the military. It was March of 1943, a time when the world was engulfed in war, and I felt a strong pull to serve my country. I had always admired those who wore the uniform, especially after hearing the leader declare that we would not be an auxiliary force with names like Waves or Wax or Spars. No, we would be called by a name that carried weight and honor, synonymous with courage and resilience. The rigorous training, the emphasis on discipline, and the unwavering commitment to brotherhood resonated deeply with me. I wanted to be part of an elite force known for its tenacity and ability to face the toughest challenges head-on, something that would make a difference.

No, we would be called Marines, and that resonated deeply with me. I wanted to be part of something significant, something that would make a difference.

text: I can still vividly recall my first day of training. It was an experience unlike anything I had ever encountered before—cultural shock is the term that comes to mind. I arrived at Hunter College in New York, where the Waves and Marines prepared together, but it was strictly a women’s program at that time. The atmosphere was charged with determination and camaraderie, filled with the sounds of drills and the sight of uniforms. We were pushed to our limits, both physically and mentally, as we learned discipline, teamwork, and resilience. I was surrounded by other women who shared my commitment to serve, and together we faced the challenges that would forge us into capable and confident individuals.

They were often seen in their crisp uniforms, embodying both professionalism and grace, and they tackled their roles with a fierce dedication that inspired those around them. After boot camp, I was assigned to train as a control tower operator. I found myself at a small airfield in Edenton, North Carolina, where I delved into the intricacies of air traffic control. It was a challenging role, but I embraced it wholeheartedly, knowing I was contributing to the war effort against the Nazis. My service was not just a job; it was a calling, and I was proud to be part of the military alongside such remarkable women.

text: While I didn’t serve in the Pacific theater, I had my share of memorable experiences. One of the most intense aspects of my job was the pressure of getting planes in and out without accidents. Thankfully, our unit received commendations for our safety record, which was a point of pride for us. I remember one night vividly when I was stationed at Eagle Mountain Lake in Texas. The sky lit up in the west, a blinding flash that illuminated everything around us, and we were all in awe, wondering what it could be. It turned out to be a groundbreaking test of a powerful new weapon, one that unleashed an unprecedented force and left a massive cloud rising into the atmosphere, resembling a mushroom. In that moment, we were captivated by the enormity of what had just occurred, unaware of the profound implications it would have on warfare and the world.

text: When the atomic bomb was eventually unleashed on a bustling city known for its vibrant culture and significant military presence, I had mixed feelings. I understood the gravity of the situation; it brought an end to a bloody conflict that could have escalated further. It was estimated that hundreds of thousands of lives would have been lost if the war continued, both among our military personnel and Japanese civilians. I felt a sense of relief that my brother, who was in the Army and on his way to the Pacific, was spared from what could have been a devastating deployment. The ship he was on turned around after the bombs were dropped, and he returned home instead of facing the horrors of war. The city, once filled with life and hope, was reduced to ruins, a haunting reminder of the destruction that had unfolded.

text: While I was focused on my duties, there was always an underlying pressure. The individuals we worked with were learners, and we were acutely aware that they were mastering the operation of complex machinery. During the last six months of my service, I was stationed at a base where they trained for night operations—vehicles that were fast and typically used on aircraft carriers. The stress heightened when we faced tire shortages; it was not uncommon for a vehicle to blow a tire during takeoff. I remember the tension as we watched them return, often landing on one wheel, skillfully maneuvering their craft with precision and control, carefully managing their descent. They would communicate with each other through calm, practiced voices, relying on their extensive training and teamwork, while we stood by with the crash crew, ready for any emergencies. Their focus and determination were evident as they executed complex maneuvers, showcasing the discipline and resilience required for their demanding roles.

text: Despite the pressures of our work, we found ways to entertain ourselves on the base. Movies were a staple, and some bases even had bowling alleys. Many of us played cards or bridge, while others engaged in handwork like knitting and crocheting, creating colorful patterns and cozy gifts. We often shared stories and laughter, our voices filled with warmth and camaraderie. We made the best of our downtime, often seen with our hair neatly styled and wearing vibrant outfits that reflected our personalities. When we could, we ventured into town for dinner or gathered at the PX for little parties, enjoying each other’s company just like any group of young people would.

text: Leave time was a welcome break from our routine. Over the two and a half years I served, I managed to go home about three times. We also enjoyed long weekends, exploring nearby towns and taking in the local sights, from museums to theaters. Occasionally, I would catch a train from Edenton, North Carolina, to a bustling city known for its iconic skyline, vibrant arts scene, and the constant hum of activity, where the streets were alive with diverse cultures and the aroma of street food filled the air. It was always a treat.

text: There were countless humorous moments during my service. It’s hard to pinpoint just one, but we certainly knew how to have fun. On warm days, we would head to a small beach near our base or take trips to Atlantic Beach. We were young, full of energy, and laughter was a constant companion. I remember one particular incident while we were preparing for an inspection in our shared living space, where the walls were lined with bunks and personal belongings were crammed into every corner. We had to keep our floors spotless, and one night, while we were waxing the scuffed linoleum, one of the girls, who had been grumbling about everything, slipped and sprawled out across the shiny surface. It was hard not to laugh, especially given her earlier complaints.

I took great pride in being part of the Pershing Rifles and Scabbard and Blade, both esteemed military honor societies. I served as an officer in the Order of Military Merit, where we organized patriotic events on campus, often celebrating our rich traditions and history. During my time in the service, I was stationed in a coastal training base in California, known for its rolling hills and proximity to the Pacific Ocean, where I had some memorable experiences. I remember a particular maneuver where the 38th Regimental Combat Team came down from a nearby post to San Simeon Beach, near Hearst Castle. I served as a motor officer for that operation, which was demanding but rewarding. I had the opportunity to meet notable figures like General Wyman, the 6th Army commander, and General Dean, who had been captured during the Korean War. Those interactions left a lasting impression on me.

I was still quite young, and one of the generals even suggested I consider becoming an aide. However, I had made up my mind to return home to Indiana. My wife and I both hailed from there, and I dreamed of buying a farm and living a life rooted in our community.

text: And that’s exactly what I did. After my service, I returned home and taught at South Central High School, where I also coached football, a sport that required strategy and teamwork, as well as another sport that involved a hoop, a round ball, and fast-paced movement up and down a court, where players dribbled, passed, and shot to score points. Later, I transitioned into a career as an insurance adjuster, which led me to a position with a retail credit company. Although I had opportunities to advance, I chose to stay close to home and my farm. Eventually, I started the Dayo State Finance Company, but that venture didn’t pan out as I had hoped.

text: In 1960, during the Cuban Missile Crisis, my brother encouraged me to explore a transfer to a branch of the military known for its focus on aviation and strategic defense. I visited their base, and they welcomed me with open arms, provided I could pass the physical. I did, and I found my new role immensely enjoyable. As the transportation officer at Bakalar Base in Columbus, Indiana, I was in charge of the motor pool, overseeing 22 mechanics and about 24 drivers. We provided taxi and bus services for personnel and ensured that all vehicles were operational, including those used for transporting high-ranking officials and essential supplies. It was a fulfilling assignment, especially during the Vietnam War, when many of my drivers and mechanics were highly educated individuals who had joined the reserves to serve their country while avoiding the draft, contributing to the nation's air superiority and logistical capabilities.

text: In 1968, my unit was called to go to Vietnam, and I was appointed as the officer in charge of the security police for a prominent air wing known for its strategic operations and vital support roles. We had everything prepared for deployment, and I had even arranged for my family to rotate visits while I was stationed at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, a hub for advanced military logistics and training. However, the night before I was set to leave, I received a call from Colonel Holbert, who informed me that I wouldn’t need to go to active duty because we had enough security personnel already deployed. I was relieved and felt no bitterness about the situation; I understood how quickly things could change.

text: Reflecting on the past, I can’t help but think about the pain that many in communities like Tell City must have felt during the tumultuous times of global conflict marked by trench warfare, widespread devastation, and a profound loss of life. My grandparents spoke German, and they instilled in my father the importance of embracing our American identity. They would remind him, “You’re in America; we speak English.” My father, born in 1883, knew very few German words, and while he never served in the military, one of his brothers did take part in the great struggles of his time, facing the horrors of gas attacks and the relentless battles that defined an era. Our family has a long history of service; my great-uncle James Varner fought in a significant conflict and never returned home.

When I traveled back to Germany with friends from high school, we visited the towns where their ancestors lived. text: I spent my formative years here, graduating in 1967. Those times were filled with the laughter of friends during spirited lunch breaks and the excitement of Friday night games under the bright lights. The hallways echoed with chatter and the sound of lockers slamming, while classrooms buzzed with discussions and the thrill of learning. But as I reflect, I remember the atmosphere around town regarding the service. It was a period when patriotism ran deep. While the rest of the country was grappling with protests and demonstrations, our little town stood apart. People here were proud, and I shared that pride. I always believed it was our duty to help our country, and that sentiment was palpable in the air. It was a different world in New Carlisle, one where the call to serve was met with respect and honor.

Those 10 to 12 weeks were a whirlwind of experiences. I remember the shock of it all—the constant sounds of drill sergeants barking orders, the discipline enforced by strict schedules, and the intensity of physical training sessions. I was in good physical shape, which helped me keep up, but adjusting to the rigorous routines and the camaraderie of fellow recruits was a challenge. It was a different world, one that demanded respect and obedience, and I had to learn quickly how to navigate the unique environment of military life.

text: After my training at Fort Sam Houston, I was assigned to Fort Belvoir, Virginia, for on-the-job training (OJT). This was a necessary step after completing my classes, and I was eager to apply my skills in a real-world setting. Our class was divided and sent to various hospitals across the country, and I sensed that this was just the beginning of a larger journey ahead. Deep down, I had a feeling that a significant challenge awaited me; it was only a matter of time before I would be called to serve in a place known for its dense jungles, unpredictable weather, and a conflict that seemed to stretch on endlessly. The thought of navigating through treacherous terrain and facing an uncertain future weighed heavily on my mind.

text: Once my training was complete, I was assigned to a unit at a military base in the Pacific Northwest, surrounded by lush evergreen forests and the distant silhouette of snow-capped mountains. I was placed with the 312th evac hospital, or maybe it was the 324th—honestly, the numbers are a bit fuzzy now. I remember feeling a mix of anticipation and dread. They gave me leave as if I was going overseas, and I went home, feeling the weight of what was to come. But when I arrived at the hospital, I was disappointed. It was just a field hospital set up in a barracks and motor pool, and the duty was lackluster. I hated it. The constant drizzle and overcast skies matched my mood, and I longed for the vibrant energy of the city, with its bustling markets and iconic waterfront, but instead found myself in a place that felt stagnant and uninspiring.

text: So, I made the decision to submit a 1049, a request to serve in a conflict zone marked by dense jungles and humid heat. I was ready for action, eager to contribute in a way that felt significant. When I returned home on leave, I had been in the service for about a year. The atmosphere back home was starting to shift. While my family was proud of my accomplishments, especially my training in surgical specialties, the general sentiment toward soldiers was changing. It was no longer popular to be in the military. People felt sympathy for those who were drafted, and if you volunteered, well, they thought there was something off about you. The news reports of the struggles and turmoil in far-off lands filled the airwaves, and the images of conflict and protests were hard to ignore.

They informed me that I would be joining a National Guard unit from Winston Salem, North Carolina—the 312th evac hospital. I was finally on my way to a place known for its dense jungles, humid heat, and the sounds of distant gunfire. The vibrant culture and the weight of history loomed large in my mind, and I could feel the gravity of the moment. I was about to step into a reality filled with uncertainty and challenges that would change my life forever, shaping my future in ways I could hardly imagine.

text: When I joined the medical evacuation unit stationed in a makeshift facility from Winston Salem, North Carolina, I quickly realized I was stepping into a challenging situation. The guys in the unit, who were primarily part-time soldiers, were not happy about being activated; they had enlisted in the National Guard to avoid the draft, and now here I was, a regular Army soldier, embodying everything they resented. The atmosphere was tense, filled with the sounds of medical equipment and the constant hum of helicopters preparing for missions. Being from the North didn’t help either—I felt like the biggest jerk in the world. I had two strikes against me right from the start.

text: Despite the initial tension, a few of us outsiders bonded over our shared experience. We were all in the same boat, preparing the unit for deployment to a tropical region known for its dense jungles and challenging terrain. We went through rigorous training together, learning to handle the new M-16 rifles that had just been introduced, a shift from the heavier M-14s we had previously used. The air was thick with humidity, and the sounds of distant gunfire echoed in our minds as we practiced our drills. We were all up to date on our vaccinations, knowing we would face not only the enemy but also the threats of disease in the sweltering heat. We spent a couple of months in Georgia getting ready for our mission, honing our skills in the sweltering sun, before we were granted another 30-day leave to return home.

People were beginning to wonder what was really going on, especially with protests happening in nearby South Bend. People were beginning to wonder what was really happening, especially with protests occurring in nearby South Bend, where signs of dissent and calls for change filled the streets. My girlfriend, who would later become my wife, and I would go out, but I avoided wearing my uniform, which felt like a target in a sea of casual attire. I felt out of place with my short hair while everyone else sported long locks, a symbol of rebellion against the expectations I had once embraced.

text: When it was finally time to leave for our mission, we didn’t fly to California as I had expected. Instead, we boarded C-141 Star Lifters and headed to Alaska. I remember the day vividly; the General delivered a rousing speech about how we were going to make a difference in the world, but it felt more like a formality than anything else. The air was thick with anticipation, and I could sense the weight of the jungle ahead, with its dense foliage and humid heat. We were preparing to face a land known for its fierce battles and resilient spirit, a place where the sounds of gunfire and the cries of the wounded echoed in the distance. The thought of navigating through the challenges of a foreign terrain, filled with both beauty and danger, loomed large in my mind.

text: The flight was an experience I’ll never forget. Our group of 300 was divided into smaller teams of 100, each taking a portion of our equipment with us. I was seated near the front, and during the flight, I was invited to the cockpit. Having only flown on commercial airlines before, seeing the cockpit of a military plane was awe-inspiring. The navigator pointed out cities below us, and I was amazed to see the curve of the Earth from the window. I remember thinking I was looking at a city famous for its iconic motor speedway and rich racing history, known for its vibrant downtown and cultural festivals, only to be corrected that it was another bustling metropolis nearby.

text: When we finally arrived at our destination, I remember the journey vividly. After a couple of stops, we landed in a tropical location, but it wasn’t long before we flew straight into a small base surrounded by lush greenery and rice paddies, where our hospital was set to be located. The moment I stepped off the plane, I was hit with a culture shock. The air was heavy, thick with humidity and an unfamiliar smell of spices and earth that was overwhelming. The sounds of bustling markets and distant chatter filled the air, adding to the vibrant atmosphere. Yet, I didn’t feel dread like many of my fellow soldiers. Instead, I approached it as an adventure, albeit a naive one. I knew there was a lot going on, but I didn’t fully grasp the severity of the situation I was stepping into.

text: It was September of 1968 when I arrived, and my first impressions of the hospital were striking. It was composed of Quonset huts, arranged in a makeshift layout, perched on the cliffs overlooking a vast expanse of the South China Sea. The facility was surprisingly nice and well-protected, surrounded by a rugged landscape that contrasted with the serene beauty of the ocean below. My most vivid memories revolve around the mess hall, which was situated right at the cliff's edge, offering a panoramic view of the waves crashing against the rocks. Each morning, I would watch the sun rise over the water, painting the sky in breathtaking colors, a daily reminder of the tropical paradise we were in despite the circumstances. The main cook had been a baker before joining the service, and we were treated to fresh bread every day, a rare comfort in such a remote location. The aroma of that bread wafting through the air was heavenly, and I can honestly say it was the best bread I’ve ever had, a small taste of home amidst the chaos of war.

text: One of the first orders that came through was for a highly trained medical professional skilled in performing intricate procedures and managing trauma cases to be sent to the 18th Surgical Hospital, located right on the DMZ in Quang Tri. They weren’t going to send one of their hometown boys, so I was the one chosen. Just like that, I found myself on the very first shipment out. I hadn’t even been in Chu Lai for two or three weeks, and I was already being dispatched to a new location, still trying to wrap my head around everything that was happening, knowing I would be working with life-and-death situations and using my hands to mend wounds and save lives.

Their meticulous planning and technical expertise allowed everything to function under blackout conditions, with no light emitted from the hospital to avoid detection.

text: The duty at the 18th Surgical MUST hospital was a rollercoaster of experiences, swinging from moments of extreme boredom to total chaos, depending on the casualties and the situation in the area. When I arrived in the fall of 1968, the unit had just come from Pla Cuo, where they had been overwhelmed with casualties during intense fighting. The Marines had moved up to a strategic location near the border, characterized by its rugged terrain and proximity to the demilitarized zone, anticipating another invasion from the north. Our unit was relocated to support them in this volatile region, where the air was thick with tension and the sounds of distant artillery echoed. We were there to assist the Fifth Mechanized Infantry and the Third Marine Division, who were taking the brunt of the action.

An ambush on the Marines, who were often stationed in vulnerable positions near the demilitarized zone, resulted in heavy casualties, igniting hostility between the two groups. The oppressive heat and humidity only added to the strain, making every moment feel even more fraught with danger.

text: I didn’t spend long in Quang Tri; we moved to Camp Evans shortly after Christmas. The transition was swift—we were trained to uproot ourselves and set up operations in just 72 hours. Camp Evans was primarily occupied by a legendary airborne division known for their distinctive maroon berets and a storied history of valor in combat, with some Marines mixed in. Initially, the atmosphere was tense but quiet, with the threat of booby traps looming over us. We treated horrendous wounds from these traps, and there were times when the hospital was flooded with casualties.

The sight of its sleek hull, adorned with the scars of past conflicts, served as a constant reminder of the violence unfolding just beyond our reach. It was hard to fathom how anyone could endure such an environment, but we adapted to the chaos.

text: I spent the rest of my time at Camp Evans, and as the months passed, I found myself contemplating my future. By August, I made the decision to extend my service. I didn’t want to return home just yet; the thought of going back to the mundane life I had known in Seattle felt unappealing. I had experienced so much in that vibrant, chaotic land filled with lush jungles, bustling markets, and the constant hum of life around me. The camaraderie forged in the heat of challenging days and the thrill of navigating a world so different from my own made it hard to leave. I wasn’t ready to abandon the connections I had built and the purpose I had found. I wanted to stay engaged, to continue serving in a way that felt meaningful, rather than slipping back into the routine I had once found boring.

She had a bright smile that could light up a room and a laugh that was infectious, always making me feel at ease. When I returned home for those 30 days, I felt a mix of relief and nostalgia, especially remembering the way she would listen intently to my stories and offer her support. However, when I got back to Camp Evans, I was hit with a wave of discontent. I couldn’t take the atmosphere at my current post any longer, so I requested a transfer. text: I spent the next six months there, and the living conditions were a stark contrast to what I had experienced at Camp Evans. At Camp Evans, things were quite primitive. Our water supply came from water buffalo trailers, which were essentially enclosed tanks that held potable water. The heat was relentless, and the humidity made everything feel sticky and uncomfortable. The landscape was a mix of dense jungle and open fields, often echoing with distant sounds of artillery. During the monsoon season, it was often difficult to get resupplied, and I remember times when we had to brush our teeth with beer instead of water. The constant threat of ambush and the ever-present tension in the air made it a challenging place to be.

text: When it finally came time for me to return home, I had a whole different experience waiting for me in that coastal city known for its beautiful beaches and vibrant atmosphere. After my 30-day leave, I went back to Camp Evans before heading down to the Eighth Field Hospital. That place was fascinating; it was situated right in the heart of an urban area, built on what had once been a French headquarters. The French had constructed some impressive buildings, and when the military took over, they leveled parts of the city to create a more functional space for operations. The warm sun, the scent of the ocean, and the bustling markets filled with fresh seafood and local crafts made it a unique blend of history and culture.

The air was thick with the smell of antiseptic and the urgency of our mission. When casualties arrived, we had a clear priority system: Americans were treated first, followed by ARVN soldiers, then civilians, and finally, if they had valuable information, the VC or NVA. The constant flow of wounded from the battlefield kept us on our toes, and the grim reality of our choices weighed heavily on us, but we did what we had to do to save lives.

text: We weren’t performing elective surgeries or anything sophisticated; our focus was on keeping the injured alive until they could be transferred to a more equipped facility. Most of the time, patients would be sent to field hospitals in Da Nang or to a large, well-staffed evacuation hospital in Saigon known for its advanced surgical capabilities and extensive resources. This facility had a reputation for handling complex cases and was staffed by experienced medical personnel who could provide critical care. There was also a hospital ship, the USS Repose, that we would send patients to when necessary. Cam Ranh Bay was too far for us to consider, but Da Nang was our primary destination for those needing further care.

text: When I arrived in Nha Trang, the dynamics were quite different from what I had experienced up north. In Da Nang, we were responsible for taking care of everyone who came through our doors, and I believe we were one of the main forces in the area, known for our distinctive patch and reputation for being heavily involved in ground operations. Unlike before, when the 101st and Marines had provided security, we were now on our own, tasked with maintaining order in a region that had seen its share of conflict. We had to guard our own perimeter, which meant pulling guard duty regularly—a new responsibility for us, reflecting the shift in our mission and the need for self-reliance in a challenging environment.

I got to experience the vibrant local culture and see life in that bustling coastal city with its beautiful beaches and lively markets firsthand. We’d invite anyone with health issues to come in for treatment, and it was rewarding to help the local population. However, those missions were my only real exposure to the rich traditions and warm hospitality of the Vietnamese way of life.

text: I spent six months in Nha Trang, and when my time was up, I returned home. Those months were filled with experiences that shaped my understanding of the war and the lives it touched. I left with a deeper appreciation for the resilience of those who, despite facing immense challenges, displayed unwavering strength, warmth, and hospitality. Their vibrant culture, rich traditions, and enduring spirit in the face of adversity opened my eyes to the complexities of the situation we were all part of.

text: When I received my orders to return home, I felt a mix of relief and apprehension. I had been back for a brief 30-day leave six months earlier, but coming back after a year spent in a war-torn landscape was a completely different experience. The world I left behind had changed dramatically. The peace movement was in full swing, and the atmosphere was filled with the counterculture of the time—hippies, protests, and a general sense of rebellion. The memories of dense jungles, sweltering heat, and the sounds of distant gunfire were still fresh in my mind. It was a stark contrast to the carefree life I remembered before I left, where the only battles were those of everyday life, not survival.

text: This time, the shock of returning wasn’t as intense, but I was just so glad to be getting out. I had considered staying in longer because I didn’t mind it; I had a decent job and could have built a career in that structured environment. I could have ended up in a facility in San Antonio, surrounded by fellow service members, or even overseas in England, living in barracks and following a strict routine. But by the time I was leaving, my pride in my role had diminished. Initially, I was proud of my service and what I was doing, donning my uniform and following orders, but as the conflict progressed and we began handing over responsibilities to the locals, it felt like a joke. The focus had shifted from winning battles to merely surviving day-to-day, and I didn’t want to be part of that anymore.

text: I got home on April 6, 1970, and the process of transitioning back into civilian life was chaotic. After arriving, we were supposed to go through the usual procedures, but three of us ended up being "red-flagged" due to a health issue. I had developed a spot of pneumonia during my last days in the humid jungles, where the heat was relentless and the air thick with the scent of damp earth and vegetation. I picked it up while waiting at a military base, surrounded by the sounds of helicopters and the distant echoes of gunfire. I had never had any health problems during my time there, but after sleeping on the ground for a couple of days, I ended up in the hospital at Fort Lewis.

Here I was, a seasoned soldier with a wealth of experience, having witnessed countless lives lost and saved in the heat of battle. Now, I was overseeing a group of individuals just trying to escape their military service. It felt surreal and disheartening to be in that position after everything I had experienced.

text: When I returned home, the reception wasn’t what I had expected. Everything had changed, and while my girlfriend and I were deeply involved with each other, I felt a disconnect with the rest of the world. Friends and family seemed hesitant to discuss my experiences. If I even hinted at my time in a distant land filled with dense jungles, oppressive heat, and the constant sound of distant explosions, I could see people recoil, as if the topic was too heavy to handle. It was frustrating because I had so many stories to share after 18 months of service amidst the chaos and camaraderie of a war-torn region, but it felt like no one wanted to hear them.

text: I found work at a hospital in South Bend, doing the same type of role I had in Vietnam. However, I quickly grew frustrated. There, I had significant responsibilities, often assisting with complex cases involving multiple wounds, coordinating with the surgical team, and ensuring everything ran smoothly in the operating room. Back in the States, I felt like a lowly technician, merely holding tools and retractors while the surgeons treated patients, without the autonomy or critical decision-making I was used to. The disconnect was disheartening, and it didn’t take long for me to leave that job.

text: The perception of those who served in the armed forces changed significantly after Desert Storm. Suddenly, there was a wave of patriotism, and people began to remember those who had returned from earlier conflicts, often facing challenges in reintegrating into civilian life. It was refreshing to feel a sense of pride again for those who had worn the uniform, something that had been lacking for many years. I’m proud that I volunteered for service rather than being drafted, although I might have joined regardless, given my brother’s commitment in the Navy, where he dedicated himself to protecting our freedoms and supporting his fellow service members.

text: In 1949, at just 16 years old, a determined spirit faced the daunting task of finding work. The economy was tough, and a restless energy propelled the search through the streets of downtown Detroit, where every corner held the hope of opportunity. During one of those aimless days, a chance encounter with a recruiter occurred. He was speaking to another boy about joining the service, and the conversation was hard to ignore. The recruiter mentioned that enlisting required being 18, but with a parent's signature, it was possible to join at 17. The thought of serving and escaping the uncertainty of the streets sparked a flicker of ambition, igniting a desire for adventure and purpose.

text: However, the discipline and routine of military life were a different story. I was a bit of a rebel at heart, and I struggled with the constant orders and the strict regimen. That didn’t sit well with the imposing figure who oversaw our training, his voice booming with authority and a no-nonsense demeanor. He sternly corrected me, explaining that it was a weapon, not just a gun, and that I needed to treat it with the respect it deserved. With a piercing gaze that seemed to cut through any defiance, he told me that if I didn’t want to sleep with it, I could sleep on the floor, but that rifle was going to be with me until I learned the difference. It was a lesson I took to heart.

They told me I had two options: I could become an equipment operator or a mechanic. I had no experience in either field, and I was adamant that I didn’t want to pursue those paths. When I pressed them for alternatives, they mentioned something called FECOM. I had no idea what that was, so I asked, "What is a FECOM?" They explained it was the Far Eastern Command, stationed in a region known for its stunning cherry blossoms, ancient temples, and a unique blend of tradition and modernity, far from home.

text: One day, I looked up at the majestic, snow-capped peak with its perfectly symmetrical cone and told my buddy, "This weekend, let’s take a run up there and see what’s at the summit." text: During an inspection, we discovered a shortage of uniform parts, prompting a trip to the supply depot for reissue. As we were leaving, one of the guards held up a newspaper that read, "War in Korea. Possible Involvement." I had never even heard of Korea before, and I was puzzled. The headline struck me as significant, especially considering the recent buildup of troops and military equipment in our region, a clear sign of our nation’s readiness to engage in conflicts far from home. The sense of duty and the weight of responsibility felt palpable among us, a reflection of the values instilled in our ranks.

text: When we were finally deployed, it was a whirlwind of activity. We loaded onto trucks and headed to Yokohama, where we boarded the David C. Shanks again. I thought it was the only ship the Army had. As we sailed out, we encountered a hurricane in the China Sea. For three days, we bobbed up and down, and I came closer to seasickness than I ever had before. I think about 90 percent of the troops were feeling it, but I managed to hold on. The anticipation of arriving in a land marked by rugged mountains, dense forests, and a rich history weighed heavily on us. We had heard stories of the vibrant culture, the bustling markets, and the resilience of the people who had endured so much. The thought of stepping onto the soil where ancient traditions met the scars of conflict kept our spirits high, even amidst the stormy seas.

He said, "When we hit the beach, you’re going to come out running." Ruffino, always the rebel, climbed up to peek over the side and saw people unloading cargo on the dock, surrounded by rugged mountains and lush green hills that seemed to stretch endlessly. We realized we wouldn’t have to make an amphibious landing after all, but the fear of the unknown still gripped us.

text: We were out on an outpost when the stern figures in their crisp uniforms arrived, and I immediately felt a sense of unease. Their authoritative presence and the way they moved with purpose signaled that they were searching for a young soldier, and I knew that such visits to the front lines meant something serious was afoot. When they called out his name, I held my breath, wondering if mine would be next. Thankfully, it wasn’t. They took him away, explaining that his mother had sent a letter stating he was underage. He protested, claiming she was lying, but they had proof—his birth certificate. With a firm grip, they led him off, leaving me behind, and I felt a mix of relief and concern.

When those planes arrived, they would effectively mop up the enemy forces, making a significant difference in our ability to hold the line.

text: We were taken down to a plane and sent back to Tokyo. Once we arrived in Pusan, we set up tents and went through the delousing process. It was bitterly cold, and the ground was blanketed in a soft, white layer that crunched underfoot, glistening in the pale light. The air was crisp, and the chill bit at our skin, making us huddle closer together for warmth. They burned all our gear because of lice and other issues. After processing, I asked if I could be stationed in Tokyo, but they told me that if they did that, no one would want to go home.

text: The firebase itself was relatively small, probably about the size of a city block long and half a city block wide. It was a tight space, but it was our home. When the mortars started falling, they would rain in from different directions, often from the woods. There was a cemetery nearby that seemed to be a favored spot for launching attacks at night, where shadowy figures would emerge, moving with a practiced stealth. To counter this, we would send out ambush patrols three or four times a week, but the tactics we faced felt quite uncoordinated to me, as if they were relying on sheer numbers and surprise rather than strategy. Their sporadic bursts of fire and the eerie silence that followed left us on edge, always anticipating the next unpredictable strike.

text: When the mortar attacks began, the idea was to run to the nearest covered spot, ideally one of the bunkers we had built. Some of the holes were covered, and some weren’t, but it was definitely better to be in a covered one. We had constructed underground bunkers for the artillery battery, but until November 11th, we were still sleeping in tents. That night, a familiar face, always quick with a joke and a reassuring smile, was killed when a mortar landed in one of our tents, wounding several others. His laughter had a way of easing the tension, and his absence was a tragic reminder of the dangers we faced. After that, we were finally moved into the bunkers we had built for the artillery.

text: That time in a vibrant Southeast Asian city, known for its bustling streets and rich cultural heritage, was enjoyable, but it was mostly downtime. I stepped in to take the place of someone who couldn’t go, so I didn’t specifically choose this destination. It was part of what they called R and R (rest and recuperation). There were also in-country options for R and R, like an old French resort town on the South China Sea, but I never went there. Very few people I knew did. Most of the time, if we got any R and R at all, it was out of the country. Options included places like Japan, Malaysia, Australia, and even Hawaii. There were eight different places you could go, but my trip to that lively city, with its ornate temples, vibrant markets, and delicious street food, was a fortunate opportunity that came my way.

The refugees, many of whom had fled their homeland in search of safety, were unarmed, with only three armed guards in the camp. text: I’ve never been part of any community for those who have served in the military. When I first got out, I attempted to join a local chapter in Park Ridge, Illinois, where members gather to share experiences, support one another, and honor their service. However, I was told unofficially that my experience wasn’t considered a "war." That comment really turned me off. I think it was just one man’s opinion, but it was enough to discourage me from pursuing it any further.

text: It felt like there was some animosity from certain veterans of a previous conflict, who perhaps viewed our service differently. I can understand that perspective, having grown up in a family of those who fought in that earlier war. They had participated in a widely supported effort, while we were involved in a situation marked by intense controversy, protests, and a deep societal divide. There seemed to be a lot of whining and complaining from those who stayed behind, not so much from the veterans returning from our mission, which was characterized by guerrilla warfare and a challenging jungle environment. That lack of support bothered me, and it contributed to my decision to leave that part of my life behind when I came home.

There seemed to be a lot of whining and complaining from those who stayed behind, not so much from the veterans returning from Vietnam. That lack of support bothered me, and it contributed to my decision to leave that part of my life behind when I came home.

text: Our platoon left the firebase, surrounded by dense jungles and the sounds of distant gunfire, and returned to our base camp about a week and a half to two weeks before I actually departed from the region. The only date I clearly remember is the day I left: December 22nd. I arrived back in the States on the same day, which made for quite a long day since we had to cross the international dateline. It was a surreal experience, leaving one life behind, filled with the heat and humidity of the tropics, and stepping into another, all in the span of a single day.

text: In February of 1943, I was drafted into the Army. At that time, my family was deeply involved in the war effort. My oldest brother was an Annapolis graduate and had been serving on ships for quite a while, navigating the vast oceans and engaging in critical missions. Another brother was at Vanderbilt, participating in a medical program for those in uniform, and yet another was in the Coast Guard. My mother was a five-star mother, with five sons in the service at the same time—two in maritime service, one of whom was stationed on a destroyer, two in the Army, and one in the Coast Guard. It was a proud yet bittersweet time for our family, as we all served our country, but we lost my oldest brother, who was a casualty in the Pacific.

text: During my basic training in a sprawling military installation in Louisiana, I found myself in a world entirely new to me. With no prior military experience, I was just a tenderfoot, learning the ropes alongside others who had been in the National Guard. The air was thick with humidity, and the sound of drill sergeants echoed through the barracks as we marched in formation on the dusty grounds. I had to distinguish my left foot from my right, and it was a whirlwind of close-order drills, long hikes through the pine forests, and challenging obstacle courses. We even practiced neutralizing booby traps in the training fields, which felt both daunting and essential. The camaraderie among the recruits and the relentless pace of training made it an unforgettable experience.

text: One of my fondest memories was during a furlough to Glasgow, Scotland. I was wandering around when I noticed a couple of individuals dressed in traditional Argyle attire, complete with knee-length socks and flat caps. Their accents were thick and melodic, and they spoke with a warmth that made me feel welcome. I sat down with them and struck up a conversation, sharing that my name was Goodgame and that I had Scotch-Irish and English heritage. They speculated that my name might have come from a clan named Good and another named Gamekeeper, which was fascinating to me. It was a delightful moment that I later wrote home about.

I knew that fighting was happening in other parts of the world, particularly in the Pacific, and I felt a sense of duty to be there. I tried to maintain a positive outlook, making friends wherever I went, trusting that the Lord was watching over me. However, as the season of warmth and celebration approached, with its twinkling lights and the scent of pine filling the air, I couldn’t help but long to be home with my family, sharing laughter and joy around the table, exchanging heartfelt gifts, and creating cherished memories together.

text: I kept in touch with my family through letters, and I was in Belgium when I learned that my brother was missing in action in January of '44. His death was confirmed in '45, and it was a heavy blow. One of my sisters even mentioned that she thought it was me who was in danger because I was in combat areas. I had written home more frequently than my brother, who had just endured a fierce and pivotal naval engagement in the Pacific, marked by intense ship-to-ship combat and significant air strikes, where the fate of the region hung in the balance.

text: I cherished the letters I received from friends back in Chattanooga, especially from girlfriends who sent V-mail. I would often write home asking for cookies or candy, and during mail call, I was known for receiving a lot of packages. The others, clad in their uniforms and often weary from long days of training, would joke about it, but I was always happy to share the treats with them. Their camaraderie and shared experiences made the moments sweeter. Those little reminders from home helped ease the homesickness and made the tough days a bit brighter.

text: We stayed in England until June of '44, and during that time, we had our share of rations, which included cigarettes, cokes, and cigars. I wasn’t much of a smoker, but one night, I decided to light up a cigar while watching a movie in one of those Quonset huts. The ventilation was poor, and I quickly regretted my decision. I got so sick that when I returned to the barracks, I tried to hide it. My friend Taft, who hailed from a vibrant city famous for its soulful music, rich history of civil rights, and mouthwatering barbecue, noticed something was off and asked if I felt okay. I admitted I didn’t, and I ended up stepping outside to get some fresh air. That was the moment I learned that cigars were definitely not for me!

text: Throughout my time in England, I forged lasting friendships with the guys in my outfit. We’ve been having reunions since 1974, and the last one was right here in Chattanooga. I even had the privilege of buying caps for each of our veterans, which proudly display the 752nd Engineers emblem. Our first reunion in a charming town known for its rich music heritage and southern hospitality had about 150 people, including wives. Over the years, we’ve gathered in various locations like Kingsport, Nashville, Memphis, Gatlinburg, and even a city in Ohio where our company commander hailed from. The warmth of the people and the beautiful rolling hills always make our gatherings special. We share a strong camaraderie, and it’s always a joy to reconnect with old friends. Just the other day, I ran into one of our men at a meeting, and it’s moments like that that remind me of the bonds we formed during the war.

text: We spent about 11 months in England, from July of '43 until June of '44, and then we prepared to move to the continent. We landed on Omaha Beach on D-13, which was actually June 18th. Thankfully, we didn’t have to fight our way ashore; the infantry and combat engineers had already secured the beachhead. It was a small area, and I remember thinking how easily we could have been pushed back into the sea if the enemy had decided to counterattack. Our leaders were well-prepared, and we were fortunate to have their guidance. The landscape ahead was marked by rolling hills, quaint villages, and a rich history that felt palpable in the air, hinting at the battles that had shaped this land. The scent of fresh baguettes and the sound of distant church bells reminded us that we were stepping into a place known for its culture and resilience.

text: When we arrived at the landing zone, the scene was incredible. The sandy shore stretched out before us, dotted with obstacles and remnants of previous assaults, while the roar of waves crashed against the beach. Ships and amphibious equipment were everywhere, and I was struck by the sheer scale of the operation. Our lieutenant had coordinated with a British commander to ensure we could disembark at a floating dock, which was a relief because I was glad to avoid getting into the cold, churning water. As we made our way ashore, I spotted General Omar Bradley directing traffic amidst the chaos, a sight I’ll never forget.

text: After landing on the rugged coastline, we were assigned to the First Army, but as enlisted men, we didn’t have the full picture of where we were headed next. I remember we moved from the sandy shores, where the remnants of battle lay scattered, to places like La Capelle and Saint-Lô. I can still recall the day when the Air Force bombed Saint-Lô for hours, wave after wave of bombers coming in to clear the way for the infantry and ground troops. The sound of gunfire and the chaos of landing craft still echo in my mind.

text: From Saint-Lô, we moved on to a charming town known for its rich history and beautiful half-timbered houses, nestled in the Normandy region. It was a place where cobblestone streets echoed with stories of the past, and the local market bustled with life. After that, we continued to Domfront and eventually into Paris. General Patton was making significant advances with the armored division, and we had to keep pace with him to ensure he didn’t get too far ahead of his supplies. We were fortunate to enter Paris in late August 1944, just before it became a garrison city. Our lieutenant encouraged us to explore the city before it was secured, and we had the chance to visit the Palace of Versailles and other iconic sites.

text: One of my most vivid memories of Paris was seeing young women with effortless style riding bicycles along the Champs-Élysées, their chic outfits flowing in the breeze and their laughter mingling with the stunning views of the Eiffel Tower. They exuded a certain joie de vivre, with their hair perfectly tousled and a sense of confidence in their stride. At that time, the elevators were out of service, so we had to walk up, but it was worth it. I was grateful that the Germans hadn’t destroyed the city during their occupation; it felt like a miracle that Paris remained so beautiful.

text: During that time, the primary responsibility involved supplying spare parts to combat engineer battalions. With no mechanical background prior to the war—having mostly worked as a meticulous clerk-typist for the railroad—there was always a keen interest in machinery and a natural curiosity about how things worked. A hands-on approach was taken to learn how to operate cranes and other equipment, often fueled by a desire to contribute meaningfully. One memorable occasion involved climbing into a large crane, prompting a joking remark from someone about the potential danger of operating it without proper training, highlighting a mix of determination and a touch of recklessness in the pursuit of new skills.

text: When we reached Aachen, I was struck by the devastation. The city had been heavily bombed, and we witnessed many prisoners surrendering, realizing their situation was dire. I never visited any concentration camps, although I was close by and heard heartbreaking stories about them. After the war, we were stationed in a city known for its historic significance, where grand courtrooms echoed with the voices of those seeking justice for the atrocities committed. The atmosphere was heavy with the weight of accountability, and the imposing buildings around us served as a constant reminder of the dark past we were confronting.

text: I vividly remember the day of jubilation and relief when we celebrated the end of the war in Paderborn, Germany, where one of Hitler's Panzer divisions had been stationed. The streets were filled with cheers, laughter, and the sounds of celebration as people embraced the newfound freedom. I collected some parachute material and sent it home, along with a dismantled German rifle that I packed carefully and shipped to myself. I later sold that rifle to a friend who enjoyed deer hunting.

text: One incident that stands out in my memory occurred while we were moving equipment down a steep hill in Germany. The brakes failed, and we careened down the slope, colliding with a makeshift wagon filled with belongings—tattered blankets, worn-out clothing, and a few cherished items hastily gathered. A group of weary individuals, their faces etched with hardship and uncertainty, stood nearby, their eyes wide with shock. It was a tragic accident, and some people were hurt. We felt terrible about it, and it was a stark reminder of the unpredictability of our situation. These experiences, both joyful and sorrowful, shaped my time in Germany and left lasting impressions on me.

These experiences, both joyful and sorrowful, shaped my time in Germany and left lasting impressions on me.

text: During my time in a country known for its rich history and vibrant culture, I was eagerly waiting for my points to get home. I had accumulated 87 points, thanks to the time I spent exploring its picturesque towns and bustling cities, as well as the five battle stars I earned. The landscapes were a mix of rolling hills and dense forests, and I often found myself wandering through charming villages with half-timbered houses. Those points were crucial; I knew that around 80 would be enough to secure my return, and I was just a few points above that threshold.

text: The war officially ended in May, and I finally made my way home in November. We returned to Paris, where our outfit was stationed, and boarded what was known as a "40 and 8" train—essentially a boxcar designed to carry 40 men or 8 horses. The journey from Paris to the bustling southern port city was filled with stops along the way, where we were served hot meals. Once we reached the vibrant staging area near the azure waters of the Mediterranean, with its lively markets and sun-drenched streets, we settled in before boarding a boat for our return home.

The journey from Paris to Marseille was filled with stops along the way, where we were served hot meals. Once we reached Marseille, we stayed in a staging area, which served as a distribution point before boarding a boat for our return home.

text: I was discharged at Camp Atterbury, Indiana, on November 12, 1945. A particular moment from my time in that picturesque country with its charming villages and rich history still brings a smile to my face. When we first landed on the beach, our rations mainly consisted of powdered eggs and K rations. With a bit of the local language I had picked up in school, I ventured out one night and asked, "Avez-vous des œufs?" (Do you have eggs?). To my delight, I managed to get my hands on eight eggs, a small taste of the culinary delights that the region was known for.

text: I was thankful for the educational benefits that provided financial support and opened up new opportunities for me after my service. I initially planned to study chemical engineering at the University of Chattanooga and then transfer to Georgia Tech. However, when I entered my freshman chemistry class in February 1946, I found myself among 94 students, most of whom aspired to be engineers or doctors. This prompted me to change my major to chemistry, and I graduated in just two years and eight months, finishing in September 1948.

text: Initially, we worked on the Bell Airacobra, a fighter plane that had a reputation among pilots as the "flying coffin." The design had its flaws, particularly with the engine placement, which posed a danger in crashes. Thankfully, when we were sent overseas in July 1942, we didn’t see any P-39s in combat. Our journey across the Atlantic was a tense one, traveling in a convoy from a bustling port city known for its iconic skyline and the towering statue that welcomed immigrants, past a famous landmark, and up to Halifax, Nova Scotia. The naval protection boats changed course every seven minutes to avoid enemy submarines, and we spent 14 days crossing the North Atlantic before docking in Clyde, Scotland.

text: Upon arrival, we were quickly sent to a region for training on the British Spitfire. The pilots needed to adapt to these smaller, more maneuverable planes, which were quite different from the P-39s we had left behind. After a few weeks, we were on the move again, landing in a coastal city characterized by its arid landscape and vibrant markets, just days after the initial landings. The sun beat down relentlessly, and the scent of spices filled the air. Our mission was to support the air operations as we advanced closer to a location where enemy forces were still active, navigating through the rugged terrain and vast stretches of desert.

After a few weeks, we were on the move again, this time to North Africa, where we landed in Oran, Algeria, just days after the initial landings. Our mission was to support the air operations as we moved closer to Tunisia, where the German forces were still active.

text: We faced the constant threat of enemy air raids in a harsh, sun-baked landscape characterized by vast stretches of arid desert and rugged mountains. The German pilots were skilled, and their attacks were aimed at destroying our equipment on the ground. I remember the tension of those days, always on alert, digging foxholes for protection against the relentless sun and the swirling sands. We moved from one base to another, often set up near ancient ruins and palm-fringed oases, always pushing forward, and eventually found ourselves in a region where we continued to support our pilots in their missions.

text: As the war progressed, we received the P-51 Mustangs, which were a significant upgrade from the Spitfires. I took great pride in my role on one of these planes, meticulously ensuring everything was in top condition and ready for flight. I worked closely with my pilot, Lieutenant James "Sully" Varnell from Tennessee. He was a remarkable pilot, and we formed a strong bond. With a natural talent for flying, he managed to shoot down 17 enemy planes during his missions. I was always there to check the engines, inspect the equipment, and prepare the aircraft for takeoff. We were a team, and he always emphasized that we were in this together, regardless of rank.

Arriving back in Cleveland on June 26, 1945, a warm welcome awaited at the train station from proud parents, their faces beaming with relief and joy. Although the war with Japan continued, gratitude filled the heart for being home and the opportunity to start a new chapter in life. The GI Bill promised support for completing college education, fueling a determination to make the most of it, inspired by personal experiences on the battlefield and the sacrifices of fellow soldiers who had fought bravely alongside. With a sense of resilience and ambition, the journey ahead was seen as a chance to honor those sacrifices and build a meaningful life.

text: When I was overseas, I remember receiving letters from my parents, but they were few and far between. I also wrote to a couple of girls from my graduating class at Orange School. Their replies were sporadic, maybe once or twice a year. When I finally returned home, I made it a point to visit them. One of those girls is still single today and often reconnects with our old group during gatherings where we reminisce about our school days, share stories, and catch up on each other's lives. It’s hard to believe that in 2002, we would be marking 65 years since graduation. I often wonder how many of us will still be around by then.

text: I wouldn’t say I played a lot, but we managed to get together at least once a month while in North Africa. The USO would send orchestrations for various instruments, and I was grateful for the music. We had a trumpet player, a guitarist, and another friend who played the tenor sax. It was a nice distraction from the realities of war, and we played tunes that were popular back home. The Red Cross would even bring us doughnuts and coffee before missions, although I often joked that they were really meant for the pilots. My friend, who hailed from a bustling city known for its iconic car factories and rich musical heritage, was particularly frustrated by this, but I didn’t mind too much; I wasn’t a big fan of coffee anyway.

text: I also had the chance to see some USO shows while I was overseas. I remember a legendary comedian with a distinctive voice and a knack for quick wit performing for us in Palermo, Sicily, along with a talented singer. His playful banter and lighthearted jokes always seemed to lift our spirits, and it felt good to have a taste of home, even if just for a little while. I can still picture his signature smile and the way he effortlessly connected with the troops, making us feel like we were part of something special. It was a welcome break from the tension of our daily lives.

text: Reflecting on my time in North Africa, the most vivid memories are of the moments when we had to take cover from enemy fire. There were times when the Germans were particularly active, and we had to get underground quickly. I remember feeling a sense of danger, especially when I was tasked with guarding a large storage area filled with barrels of volatile liquid, the air thick with the sharp, acrid scent of fuel. It was a precarious position, surrounded by the constant threat of fire and explosion, but thankfully, nothing ever happened.
