text: I still remember that fateful Sunday when everything changed. We had just returned home from church, and I turned on the radio, expecting to hear a baseball game. Instead, I was met with shocking news about a surprise attack on a distant naval base, where ships were anchored and planes were caught off guard. The reports spoke of chaos and destruction, making the reality of war feel alarmingly close. At just 22 years old, I had already signed up for the draft back in October 1940, and I knew my time was approaching.

text: After the war, returning home brought a strong eagerness to finish an education that had been interrupted by service. With a sense of responsibility and determination to make the most of the GI Bill, a long-standing interest in teaching, especially math, emerged. A passion for learning and a desire to share knowledge with others fueled the ambition to inspire students in the same way that past teachers had inspired. Teaching began in September 1947, just a couple of years after coming home, leading to a dedicated 30-year journey in education, marked by patience, creativity, and a commitment to nurturing young minds.

I started teaching in September 1947, just a couple of years after returning home, and I dedicated the next 30 years to education.

text: I remember passing by that old structure with its peeling paint and broken windows, standing tall yet weary against the skyline. The worn steps creaked underfoot as I approached, leading up to the entrance that had seen better days. That was where I began my teaching career in September of 1947, on the uppermost floor. I was 28 years old, and the other new teachers had just graduated from college. They looked at me and joked, "Mr. Jones, you seem a bit older than we are!" I laughed and replied, "Well, I’ve had a few extra years under my belt." After returning from World War II, I had to complete two more years of college before I could earn my bachelor’s degree. I graduated in August 1947, just in time to start teaching.

text: Looking back, there are so many little stories from my time in the service. One that stands out happened during a 24-hour pass in North Africa. As I walked down a long, open road, I noticed a familiar figure trailing behind me, his tall frame slightly hunched against the wind. With a quick wit and a penchant for humor, he always found a way to lighten the mood. When I asked why he was lagging, he replied with a grin, "I thought there was no use in both of us breaking the wind!" I chuckled and said, "Well, when are you going to take your turn?" It was a lighthearted moment amidst the seriousness of our situation.

A friend and I were walking down a long, open road when the wind picked up. I turned around to find my friend walking behind me. When I asked why, he said, "I thought there was no use in both of us breaking the wind!" I chuckled and said, "Well, when are you going to take your turn?" It was a lighthearted moment amidst the seriousness of our situation.

text: While in North Africa, I also tried to buy a saxophone from a pawn shop. I thought it would be a good idea to start a little orchestra, but the French saxophone I bought was too complicated for me. I was accustomed to a design that featured a more intuitive octave key system, with a lighter build and a warmer, richer tone that felt more comfortable in my hands. After struggling with it, I decided to return it and told the shopkeeper, "I forgot what I paid for this, but here, sell it again; it’s yours." I was eager for my father to send my own instrument, the one that had always been my favorite.

text: It’s funny how life works out. If it hadn’t been for World War II, I would have never met my wife, Mary Ellen. She had enlisted to serve her country, dedicating herself to caring for those in need, but her name wasn’t drawn for overseas duty. Instead, she was stationed at Crile Hospital in Cleveland, which had been an army hospital during the war. There, she worked tirelessly alongside other medical professionals, providing support and comfort to wounded soldiers. Two of her close friends were sent overseas to tend to the injured on the front lines, but she stayed behind, and that’s how our paths crossed.

text: Mary Ellen grew up in Miami County, just north of a vibrant city known for its rich aviation history and a strong sense of community in Ohio. After completing her nursing training, she found herself at Crile Hospital. One Sunday morning, my dad invited her to church. I was already seated when she walked in, and my dad introduced us. I recognized her uniform from my time in the service; I had spent ten days in the hospital for yellow jaundice. After church, my dad offered her a ride back to the hospital, and that’s how we started dating.

text: My highest rank during my service was Buck Sergeant. I remember the day well; it was May 1st, and my name was posted on the First Sergeant's tent, indicating that I had been promoted to Staff Sergeant. I felt a sense of pride, but just a few days later, on May 7th, the atmosphere shifted dramatically, and the tension that had filled our days dissipated. I approached the First Sergeant of our unit, eager to discuss my new rank. He looked at me and said, "Things have shifted now. You won’t see anything from there." I laughed, realizing that my promotion would be just a title without the opportunity to serve in that role. So, I had to settle for Buck Sergeant, left with memories of the chaos and camaraderie that had defined our time together.
